section1.title: A blog born from the sea (and the desire to share what we love)
section1.body:
We have been navigating the waters of Alcudia Bay for years. We know every cove, every change of light throughout the day, every spot where the water shifts from turquoise to emerald. We know when the northern wind brings the perfect sailing day and when it’s better to stay ashore enjoying a coffee at the port.

After countless conversations with travellers who stepped on board full of questions —when is the best time to visit? where do locals really eat? which coves don’t appear in guidebooks?— we realised it was time to gather all that knowledge in one accessible place.

That’s how this blog was born: not as a marketing tool, but as a natural extension of what we do every day. We want anyone arriving in Mallorca looking for something authentic to find honest answers, practical advice and, above all, inspiration to experience the Mediterranean in a different way.

section2.title: Who we are: the story behind Coral Boats
section2.body:
Coral Boats is not just another boat tour company. We are a family project, born from a deep passion for the sea and for this island we call home.

Our boat is a traditional Mallorcan llaüt —a wooden vessel that has sailed these waters for decades. It can accommodate up to 35 people on our regular tours and up to 50 on private charters. It’s not the fastest boat, but it has something modern boats can’t replicate: soul.

We sail from the Port of Alcudia, on the north coast of Mallorca. It’s a privileged area: the bay is sheltered from prevailing winds, the waters are calm and crystal-clear, and there are hidden coves only accessible by boat.

The atmosphere on board Coral Boats is relaxed but lively —what we like to call Mediterranean good vibes. Background music, conversations with the skipper and crew sharing local stories, laughter, toasts with homemade sangria and the contagious energy of people enjoying the sea. We’re not a silent cruise, and we’re not a wild party boat either. We are that perfect balance where you can relax in the sun, meet new people, dance a little if you feel like it and genuinely have a great time.

section3.title: What you’ll find on this blog
section3.body: We created this space to share everything we know about the area and about sailing in Mallorca. Here you’ll find:

sub1.subtitle: Practical guides and local tips
sub1.body: From what to bring on a boat tour to how to choose the best day based on the weather. Useful information, no filler, based on real experience.

sub2.subtitle: Routes, coves and hidden spots
sub2.body: We’ll tell you about places that don’t appear in tourist guides. Coves only reachable by boat, hidden viewpoints and beaches where you can still find peace even in August.

sub3.subtitle: Life in Alcudia Bay
sub3.body: History, curiosities, gastronomy and local culture. Everything that makes this part of northern Mallorca special.

sub4.subtitle: Comparisons and help choosing
sub4.body: Catamaran or classic boat? Private or shared tour? Morning or sunset? Honest information to help you choose what fits you best.

section4.title: Our philosophy: enjoying the sea without rushing
section4.body:
Mallorca offers countless boat trips, from massive catamarans to fast boats hopping between coves.

We chose a different path. We believe the sea is best enjoyed when relaxation meets genuine fun. A good conversation with the skipper, a toast with homemade sangria while watching the horizon, music, laughter and swims in crystal-clear coves —these are the moments that stay with you.

We don’t want you to step on board and feel bored. We want you to relax, laugh, meet interesting people, taste local flavours and step off the boat thinking: “That was amazing.”

This blog reflects that philosophy. No constant sales pitches, just real stories, useful knowledge and a genuine love for this corner of the Mediterranean.

section5.title: A commitment to authenticity
section5.body:
Everything we write here comes from direct experience. When we recommend a restaurant, we’ve eaten there. When we talk about a cove, we’ve visited it countless times. When we give navigation advice, it’s because we learned it on the water.

That means we’ll sometimes be critical. If something isn’t worth it, we’ll say so. If another option suits a certain traveller better than ours, we’ll say that too.

This blog will grow slowly, with carefully crafted articles. Quality over quantity, always.

section6.title: Thank you for being here
section6.body:
If you’ve read this far, you probably share part of our way of seeing things. Maybe you value authentic experiences over mass tourism. Maybe you love the sea as much as we do.

Whatever your reason, thank you for your time. We hope this blog inspires you to discover Mallorca differently —and maybe one day, we’ll meet sailing together in Alcudia Bay.

Welcome on board. The journey has just begun.

section1.title: Are you planning your island holiday and looking for an unforgettable experience?
section1.body:
If there is one plan that comes up year after year among visitors to the island — and that almost everyone remembers as one of the highlights of their trip — it is **taking a boat trip in Mallorca**.

Mallorca has spectacular beaches from land, but there is another Mallorca that can only be discovered by sailing: hidden coves with no road access, crystal-clear waters far from the crowds, sea caves, dramatic cliffs and a sense of freedom that can only be felt out at sea.

This article is not a generic list of tours. It is a **real, practical guide**, designed to help you choose the right experience based on how you travel: whether you come as a couple, with children, with friends or simply want to disconnect.

Here we explain why boat trips are one of the absolute must-do experiences of summer in Mallorca, which routes are the most rewarding, and how to get the most out of them.

And if you want to start exploring the available options while you read, you can begin here: [Boat trips in Mallorca from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

section2.title: Why take a boat trip in Mallorca?
section2.body:
Mallorca has more than **550 kilometres of coastline**, and a large part of its most special spots cannot be reached on foot or by car. Many of the island’s most beautiful coves are only accessible from the sea.

A boat trip in Mallorca allows you to:

- Access **unspoilt, less crowded coves**, even during high season.
- Swim in turquoise waters with exceptional visibility.
- Enjoy snorkelling among posidonia meadows and marine life.
- Take in the landscape at a relaxed pace, far from the noise of the beach.
- See the island from a completely different perspective.
- Experience **unforgettable sunsets** over the Mediterranean.

In addition, many boat tours include drinks on board, swimming stops, explanations from the skipper and an easy-going rhythm that turns the outing into a complete experience rather than just a transfer.

Especially in areas like the **Bay of Alcudia**, where the sea is usually calm and well protected, boat tours are suitable for all types of travellers, including families with children.

If you want to explore this type of experience in more detail, we also recommend reading: [Boat trips for families with children in Mallorca](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/boat-trips-families-children-mallorca).

section3.title: The best routes to enjoy by boat
section3.body: Although Mallorca’s entire coastline has its own charm, some routes stand out for their beauty, accessibility and overall experience. These are among the most recommended ways to enjoy the island — where the Mediterranean shows itself at its very best.

sub1.subtitle: Bay of Alcudia and a hidden cove
sub1.body:
The **Bay of Alcudia** is one of the best places in Mallorca for a boat trip. Its calm waters, wide open space and variety of landscapes make it ideal both for first-time sailors and for those who have already experienced the sea.

On this type of excursion, you sail along the coastline until you reach a **hidden cove**, usually inaccessible by land. There, longer stops are made for swimming, snorkelling and relaxing.

It is a perfect route for families, couples and groups of friends looking for a balance between sailing, swimming and enjoying the natural surroundings.

You can discover this type of experience here: [Boat tours in the Bay of Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

sub2.subtitle: Sea caves and the north coast
sub2.body:
The north coast of Mallorca is wilder and less developed. Here you will find dramatic cliffs, sea caves and coves with a more natural, untouched character.

Some excursions explore areas near **Cap des Pinar** or along the north-eastern coast, where it is possible to enter small sea caves or swim alongside spectacular rock formations.

This type of route is ideal for travellers looking for a more adventurous and scenic experience.

If this appeals to you, we recommend reading: [Five secret spots you can only discover from the sea in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/five-secret-spots-sea-alcudia).

sub3.subtitle: Sunset boat tours
sub3.body:
**Sunset boat tours** are, for many travellers, the most special moment of their holiday. Sailing as the sun slowly sinks below the horizon, with the coastline bathed in golden and pink tones, is an experience that is hard to forget.

These trips usually have a more relaxed pace, soft music, drinks on board and a very calm atmosphere. They are ideal for couples, celebrations or simply for ending the day in a memorable way.

If you are looking for this type of experience, you can find more information here: [Sunset boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-sunset-boat-tour).

section4.title: What to bring with you
section4.body:
Although boat trips are designed so that you can simply step on board and enjoy, bringing the right items makes a real difference.

We recommend that you do not forget:

- **Sunscreen** (the sun is stronger out at sea).
- Swimsuit and towel.
- Sunglasses and a hat.
- Comfortable footwear or water shoes.
- A waterproof bag for your phone.
- A light jacket if you are joining a sunset excursion.

If you want to be fully prepared and leave nothing to chance, we have put together a complete guide here: [What to bring on a boat tour in Mallorca](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/what-to-bring-boat-tour-mallorca).

In addition, during high season (June to September) it is highly recommended to **book in advance**, especially if you are looking for small groups or specific time slots.

section5.title: Are you ready to book your next boat tour?
section5.body:
Taking a boat trip in Mallorca is not just another activity on your itinerary. It is a different way of experiencing the island — of understanding its geography, its light and its deep connection to the sea.

Whether it is a relaxed cruise around the Bay of Alcudia, a trip to discover hidden coves, a family-friendly excursion or a sunset sail, there is a perfect experience for every type of traveller.

If you want to explore all available options and choose the one that suits you best, this is the perfect place to start: [Best boat trips in Mallorca from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

This summer, step on board, leave the shore behind and discover why so many travellers say that **seeing Mallorca from the sea was the best memory of their holiday**.

section1.title: Why Alcudia is different from any other destination in Mallorca
section1.body:
There are destinations you visit… and destinations that pull you in. Alcudia belongs to the second group. Located on the north coast of Mallorca, this small town combines something that’s hard to find on the island: an old town with over 600 years of history enclosed by medieval walls, kilometre-long white-sand beaches, a charming fishing port, and a sheltered bay that is probably the best place in Mallorca to enjoy calm sea conditions.

But Alcudia isn’t just a pretty postcard. It’s the perfect base to explore the entire north coast: from the wild cliffs of the [Serra de Tramuntana](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/costa-norte-mallorca-acantilados-calas-secretas) to the family-friendly sands of Playa de Muro, passing through hidden coves you can only discover by boat. It’s a place where families looking for tranquillity, couples on a romantic escape, groups of friends craving adventure, and solo travellers wanting to truly switch off all coexist.

This guide comes from years of living here and knowing every corner of the area. It’s not a generic “top 10 things to see” list. It’s what’s genuinely worth it, with practical tips so you can make the most of every day. Let’s go.

section2.title: The old town: walls, history and the most authentic market on the island
section2.body:
If there’s one thing that makes Alcudia unique, it’s its walled old town. Unlike other tourist villages, the walls here aren’t decoration: they’re real, you can walk on them, and they enclose a maze of cobbled streets where time seems to stand still.

Alcudia’s walls date back to the 14th century and are the best preserved in Mallorca. You can stroll along the top and enjoy the contrast between the medieval interior and the mountains surrounding the town. The best time to do it is at sunset, when golden light warms the stone and temperatures drop — just like we explain in our guide about [watching the sunset from the sea in Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/puesta-de-sol-alcudia-mar-inolvidable).

Inside the walls, the streets are filled with small craft shops, terrace cafés and restaurants where you can try Mallorcan cuisine without the bustle of the most touristy areas. Don’t miss the Church of Sant Jaume, the Town Hall with its clock tower, and the small Plaça de la Constitució, perfect for a coffee.

But if there’s one special day to visit the old town, it’s Tuesday or Sunday. Those days you’ll find the **Alcudia market**, one of the most authentic on the island. It’s not a tourist-only market: here you’ll find fruit and vegetables from Mallorcan farms, local cured meats, artisan cheeses, sobrasada, freshly baked ensaïmadas, and seasonal products that change throughout the year. Arrive early (before 10am) to avoid crowds and enjoy it at an easy pace.

section3.title: The 6 must-do plans you can’t miss in Alcudia
section3.body: Beyond the old town, Alcudia is a destination where every day can feel completely different. Here are the plans that, after years here, we consider essential.

sub1.subtitle: Explore the bay by boat (and discover what you can’t see from land)
sub1.body:
The [Bay of Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/magia-bahia-alcudia-tour-barco) is one of the largest and most sheltered in the Mediterranean. From the beach it’s beautiful, but from the water it’s something else. Boat trips let you access [hidden coves](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/cinco-rincones-secretos-desde-el-mar-alcudia) that are impossible to reach by land, swim in crystal-clear water away from the crowds, and see the coastline from a perspective few people know.

There are many options: from catamarans with music and a festive vibe to speedboats for the more adventurous. But if what you want is something authentic and peaceful, classic wooden boats offer a completely different experience. In our [complete guide to boat trips in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/excursiones-barco-mallorca-guia-completa) we explain the differences so you can choose well.

sub2.subtitle: Playa de Alcudia and Playa de Muro: kilometres of sand for everyone
sub2.body:
Playa de Alcudia, together with Playa de Muro (which is actually the same stretch of sand with a different name), is one of the longest beaches in Mallorca: over 10 kilometres of fine sand and shallow water that make it ideal for families with children. If you’re travelling with little ones, our [guide to coves and beaches perfect for kids](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/calas-ninos-mallorca-playas-familiares) will be useful.

The area closest to the port is busier and has all services (sunbeds, beach bars, water sports). If you want more peace, walk south towards Playa de Muro, where the crowd density drops noticeably. And if you want the most unspoilt section, continue into the area by the S'Albufera Natural Park.

sub3.subtitle: Bike route to the Alcanada lighthouse
sub3.body:
One of the most beautiful and easy routes in the area is the one from Port d’Alcudia to the [beach and lighthouse of Alcanada](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/descubre-alcanada-playa-faro-isla-alcudia). It’s around 5 km along a flat coastal path, perfect by bike (there are rentals at the port) or even on foot.

Alcanada is a small rocky-sandy beach with views of a tiny islet topped by a white lighthouse that looks straight out of a postcard. The water here is especially clear and it’s an excellent snorkelling spot. At midday there can be some people, but if you go early or at sunset, you’ll have it almost to yourself.

sub4.subtitle: S'Albufera: the most important natural park in the Balearics
sub4.body:
Just behind Playa de Muro stretches S'Albufera, the largest wetland in the Balearic Islands and one of the most important natural areas in the western Mediterranean. It’s perfect if you enjoy gentle hiking, birdwatching, or simply switching off surrounded by nature.

There are several marked trails of different lengths (from 30-minute walks to 3–4 hour routes) crossing lagoons, reed beds and pine woods. You must register at the visitor centre (free) and swimming is not allowed, but the landscape is spectacular and very different from the rest of the island. Bring binoculars if you have them: it’s easy to spot herons, flamingos, ospreys and dozens of other species.

sub5.subtitle: Snorkelling and water activities in the bay
sub5.body:
The waters of the Bay of Alcudia are ideal for water sports thanks to their calmness and clarity. Beyond the classic swim and sunbathing, you can rent paddle boards, kayaks, jet skis, or join sailing lessons.

But if there’s one thing we especially recommend, it’s snorkelling. The [marine life in the bay](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/vida-marina-bahia-alcudia-especies-mediterraneo) is surprisingly rich: posidonia seagrass meadows, schools of seabream, octopus, starfish, and with luck even a turtle. The best snorkel spots aren’t on the main beach, but in rocky areas like Alcanada or coves only accessible by boat. In our [snorkelling guide in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/snorkel-mallorca-mejores-lugares-alcudia) we detail the best locations.

sub6.subtitle: Local gastronomy: where to eat really well
sub6.body:
Alcudia has everything: from Michelin-star restaurants to beach bars serving fresh fish of the day. But what’s truly worth it is finding the places where locals actually eat.

In the old town you’ll find charming terraces to try traditional Mallorcan dishes: tumbet, frit mallorquí, pa amb oli with sobrasada, and arròs brut. At the port, waterfront restaurants offer good fish and seafood, though prices are higher. And if you want something special, try booking a [boat excursion with gastronomy included](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/sabores-mediterraneos-en-barco): eating local products while floating over turquoise water is an experience you won’t forget.

section4.title: According to your traveller profile: which plan suits you best
section4.body:
Not all of us look for the same thing on holiday. Here are recommendations depending on who you are:

**If you’re travelling as a family with young children:** Playa de Alcudia is perfect thanks to its shallow waters. Combine it with a visit to S'Albufera (they’ll love seeing animals) and a calm boat trip where they can swim and snorkel. Avoid speedboats and choose stable boats. We have a [complete guide to plans with kids in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/planes-barco-familias-ninos-mallorca).

**If you’re coming as a couple looking for romance:** Sunset from the walls, dinner in the old town, and a sunset boat trip are musts. Consider a [private tour](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/excursion-barco-privada-o-compartida) if you want total intimacy.

**If you’re travelling with friends and want fun:** Port d’Alcudia has bars and nightlife. During the day, water sports, beach time and a catamaran with music can be your best bet.

**If you’re a solo traveller or want to disconnect:** Alcanada early in the morning, walking routes through S'Albufera, and a classic boat with few passengers. Seek calm and you’ll find it.

**If you’re staying only a few days and want to see a lot:** Prioritise old town + beach one day, a boat trip the next, and a day trip to [the prettiest villages in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/pueblos-mas-bonitos-mallorca-2025) on the third. If you need itinerary ideas, check our guide on [what to see in Mallorca in 3 days](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/que-ver-mallorca-3-dias-itinerario-completo).

section5.title: Practical tips for your visit to Alcudia
section5.body:
After years here, these are the tips we give to everyone who asks:

**About transport:** Alcudia is about 55 km from Palma airport (50 minutes by car). If you don’t rent a car, there are direct buses, although having a vehicle gives you much more freedom to explore. See our [guide on how to get around Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/como-moverse-por-mallorca-transporte-alquiler-coche).

**When to go:** High season (July–August) has the best weather but also more people and higher prices. June and September are ideal: great weather, warm sea and less crowding. May and October are perfect if you prioritise tranquillity over water temperature.

**About accommodation:** Port d’Alcudia has more atmosphere and is close to the beach. The old town is quieter and more charming. Playa de Muro is the go-to option for families wanting an all-inclusive resort. More details in our guide on [where to stay in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/donde-alojarse-mallorca).

**What to bring:** Sunscreen (the sun hits hard), comfortable shoes for the old town, a swimsuit at all times, and some cash for markets. If you plan to snorkel, your own gear is always better than rental.

section6.title: What tourist guides don’t tell you: local secrets
section6.body:
After living here, there are things you only learn over time:

**The best ice cream** isn’t on the seafront, but in a small ice cream shop inside the old town. Ask any local.

**The most beautiful sunsets** aren’t from the beach, but from the walls — or better yet, from a boat in the middle of the bay watching the sun drop behind the Tramuntana.

**The market has two sides:** Sundays are more touristy and bigger; Tuesdays are more local and authentic. Both are worth it, but they’re different experiences.

**To escape the crowds**, always go early. At 8am the beach is empty, boat coves at first light are magical, and the old town at that hour smells like fresh coffee and bread from the oven.

**Wind can change your day:** The Bay of Alcudia is sheltered from the north, but when the Levante blows the sea gets choppy. Check the forecast before booking any water activity. We have a [guide on weather and navigation](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/viento-meteorologia-barco-mallorca) to help you choose the best day.

section7.title: Alcudia deserves more than a day: why it’s worth staying
section7.body:
Many people visit Alcudia as a day trip from Palma or from their resort. And yes, you can see the old town and go for a swim in a few hours. But you don’t understand Alcudia in a rush.

This is a place to wake up slowly, have breakfast on a terrace facing the sea, cycle to Alcanada, spend the afternoon floating in a hidden cove, have fresh fish for dinner at the port, and walk the walls as the sun goes down. It’s a destination best enjoyed at a different pace.

If you’re looking for a place in Mallorca that combines history, nature, spectacular beaches and that feeling of being somewhere authentic (but with everything you need for a comfortable holiday), Alcudia is probably your best choice.

And if you want to add an experience you’ll always remember, set aside a day to go sailing. The bay from the water, swimming in coves that don’t appear on maps, and the sense of freedom you get out in the middle of the Mediterranean… no resort can give you that.

See you at sea. See you in Alcudia.

section1.title: Why Mallorca from the sea feels like a different island (and why choosing well matters)
section1.body:
There is something you only truly understand once you have sailed around Mallorca: the island changes completely when you see it from the water. Cliffs that look distant from land reveal their wild character when you approach them by boat. Coves that appear as tiny dots on Google Maps turn into sheltered havens with impossibly clear water. And that Mediterranean blue, already stunning from the beach, reveals shades ranging from turquoise to emerald depending on depth and time of day.

But then comes the question every traveller eventually asks: which type of boat excursion should I choose? Because sailing along the [north coast of Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/costa-norte-mallorca-acantilados-calas-secretas) on a speedboat is not the same as doing it on a wooden boat with history. A catamaran with music and a lively atmosphere is very different from an intimate vessel where the only sound is the water brushing against the hull.

This guide is the result of years navigating these waters and hundreds of conversations with travellers who, after their excursion, told us what they expected and what they actually experienced. Some made the perfect choice. Others, very honestly, admitted they would have chosen differently if they had known then what they know now. To make sure you are in the first group, here is everything you need to know before booking.

section2.title: The first step: understand what kind of traveller you really are
section2.body:
Before comparing boats, there is a more important question: what are you really looking for in a day at sea? It sounds obvious, but most disappointments come from not thinking this through. Let’s be direct.

If you are travelling with small children, safety and comfort are your priorities. A speedboat may sound exciting to you, but for a four-year-old who needs space to move, eat on time and maybe take a nap, it can quickly become stressful. On the other hand, there are [family-friendly boat excursions](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/planes-barco-familias-ninos-mallorca) designed with a different rhythm, where children can enjoy the experience without pressure.

If what you want is to truly disconnect, think about what that means to you. Does disconnecting mean lying in the sun with a drink in hand and music in the background? Then a catamaran might be perfect. Or does it mean silence, contemplation and feeling far away from everything? Then you need something more intimate.

If snorkelling and exploring marine life are high on your list, make sure the excursion actually allows enough time for it. Some tours stop so briefly that you barely have time to put your mask on. The best [snorkelling spots near Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/snorkel-mallorca-mejores-lugares-alcudia) require calm and time to be truly enjoyed.

And if you are celebrating something special — a birthday, a farewell, an anniversary — the key question is whether you want to do it privately or don’t mind sharing the moment with strangers. Here, the difference between a [private and shared boat tour](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/excursion-barco-privada-o-compartida) changes everything.

section3.title: An honest comparison: speedboat, catamaran and classic boat
section3.body: Now let’s get straight to the point. Each type of boat offers a radically different experience. There is no universally better option, but there is one that is better for you depending on what you are looking for. Here it is, without sugarcoating.

sub1.subtitle: Speedboats: adrenaline and access to the unreachable
sub1.body:
Speedboats are the choice for those who prioritise excitement and efficiency. They can reach remote coves in minutes, offer that thrilling sensation of speed over the water, and are usually shorter but more intense excursions.

**Best part:** Access to places larger boats cannot reach. If you want to see several coves in a short time, this is the most practical option. Perfect for groups of friends looking for adrenaline.

**What you should know:** Space is limited, so comfort is not their strong point. Engine noise makes conversation difficult during navigation. They usually do not include food or onboard services beyond the basics. And if the sea is a bit rough, the impact can be uncomfortable for sensitive people or small children.

**Ideal for:** Adventurers, groups of friends, travellers with limited time who want to see a lot.

sub2.subtitle: Catamarans: space, atmosphere and a social experience
sub2.body:
Catamarans are the kings of group excursions. Their double hull provides great stability, they offer large sunbathing areas, and most include food, drinks and music. These boats are designed to enjoy the atmosphere as much as the scenery.

**Best part:** Stability (very little rocking), plenty of space to move around, relax and socialise. They often include drinks or open bar options, and some offer activities such as paddle boarding or snorkelling. Perfect if you are travelling with a large group or want to meet new people.

**What you should know:** Privacy is almost non-existent. You may share the boat with 30, 50 or even more people. The atmosphere is usually festive, with music you cannot control. Stops are often at popular coves shared with other catamarans. If you are looking for peace and a deep connection with the sea, this may not be your place.

**Ideal for:** Groups of friends, stag or hen parties, celebrations, solo travellers who want to socialise, anyone looking for a party atmosphere.

sub3.subtitle: Classic boats: authenticity, calm and an intimate experience
sub3.body:
Classic boats (llüts, schooners, traditional wooden vessels) are in a category of their own. They do not compete on speed or capacity, but on something harder to measure: the soul of the experience.

Sailing on a wooden boat that has navigated these waters for decades is a way of connecting with Mediterranean maritime tradition. The pace is slow, groups are small (usually fewer than 12 people), and the experience is designed to savour every moment. These are the boats chosen by travellers who have already tried other options and are looking for something different.

**Best part:** Real intimacy, personalised attention from the skipper, and routes that avoid overcrowded coves. They often include local gastronomy (not just generic catering) and generous time for swimming and snorkelling. The silence when the engine stops and you hear only the sea is something you never forget.

**What you should know:** They are slower, so routes cover less distance. They do not have the amenities of a modern catamaran (no jacuzzi here). And because they are intimate, you need to book earlier as places sell out quickly.

**Ideal for:** Couples, families seeking calm, photographers, travellers who value authenticity over quantity, intimate celebrations, anyone who truly wants to disconnect.

section4.title: The sailing area: why it matters as much as the boat
section4.body:
A common mistake is choosing the boat without thinking about the route. Mallorca has very different sailing areas, and each one offers a unique experience. If you are staying in [Alcudia or nearby](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/que-hacer-en-alcudia-planes-imprescindibles), you have access to one of the most protected and beautiful bays on the island.

The [Bay of Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/magia-bahia-alcudia-tour-barco) stands out for its calm waters, perfect for families and for those who want to swim without waves. From here you can reach gems such as the [Alcanada lighthouse](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/descubre-alcanada-playa-faro-isla-alcudia) or [hidden coves only accessible by boat](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/cinco-rincones-secretos-desde-el-mar-alcudia). It is an ideal area for classic boats that sail without rushing and for those who want to combine scenery, swimming and Mediterranean gastronomy.

If your idea is to explore different parts of the island, we recommend our [guide to choosing a boat tour by area in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/como-elegir-tour-barco-mallorca-guia-zonas). Each coast has its own personality: the Tramuntana is wilder and more dramatic, the south has more accessible coves, and the east combines cliffs with sandy beaches. Knowing where you want to sail will help you choose better.

section5.title: The 7 most common booking mistakes (and how to avoid them)
section5.body:
After years in this industry, we see the same patterns again and again. These are the mistakes that most often ruin experiences that could have been memorable.

**1. Choosing only by price.** The cheapest tour is rarely the best value. It often means more people on board, less time at each stop, poorer food (or none), and a generic experience. A €50 excursion where you spend the day cramped can end up costing more than an €80 one that includes everything.

**2. Not checking sea conditions.** The Mediterranean is usually gentle, but on some days the tramontana or easterly winds completely change conditions. A speedboat excursion with waves can be very uncomfortable. Always check the forecast — we have a [guide to weather and sailing in Mallorca](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/viento-meteorologia-barco-mallorca) that can help.

**3. Underestimating duration.** A 2-hour excursion is a quick ride. If you want to snorkel, eat on board and truly relax, look for tours of at least 3–4 hours.

**4. Not asking how many people will be on board.** A catamaran for 20 people is very different from one with 60. A classic boat with 6 passengers feels intimate; with 15, it starts to feel crowded. Always ask about capacity.

**5. Forgetting the essentials.** Sunscreen, hat, towel, extra swimwear… the number of people who arrive without the basics is surprising. Check our [what to bring on a boat tour checklist](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/que-llevar-a-un-tour-en-barco-mallorca) before heading out.

**6. Booking the wrong day.** If your only free day is Sunday, half the island will be at sea. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are usually much quieter.

**7. Not considering the time of day.** Mornings offer better light and calmer seas. Afternoons give you the chance to see the [sunset from the water](https://coralboats.com/es/blog-details/puesta-de-sol-alcudia-mar-inolvidable). Think about what you prefer.

section6.title: Questions you should ask before booking
section6.body:
Not all companies provide the same information upfront. Here are the key questions we recommend asking before confirming any booking:

- How many people will be on the boat that day?
- What exactly is included in the price? (drinks, food, snorkelling equipment, towels...)
- How much time is spent at each cove?
- Does the skipper know the area well? Do they speak my language?
- What happens if the weather is bad? Is it cancelled, rescheduled, or refunded?
- Can we bring our own food or drinks?
- Is there shade on board?
- Is it accessible for people with reduced mobility?

A serious company will answer without hesitation. If you notice vague or generic responses, consider it a warning sign.

section7.title: Our honest recommendation (and why we stand by the classic boat)
section7.body:
We won’t pretend to be neutral. After trying every option and listening to hundreds of travellers, we truly believe the classic boat offers something the others cannot replicate: a genuine connection with the sea and with the essence of Mallorca.

It’s not for everyone. If you want a party, loud music and socialising, a catamaran will make you happier. If you want speed and to see as much as possible in a short time, a speedboat will do the job. But if what you want is to slow time down, feel that you are living something authentic, and return home with the sensation of having truly disconnected… then a boat with history is your place.

At Coral Boats, we sail a traditional Mallorcan llüt in small groups, along routes that avoid overcrowded coves. We include local gastronomy, real time for swimming and snorkelling, and a close, personal approach because we believe that is how the Mediterranean should be experienced. It is not the cheapest option nor the fastest, but it is the one you will remember.

If this resonates with you, we invite you to discover our [boat excursions from Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/es/boat-tours-alcudia). And if you still have doubts, write to us. We would rather help you choose well — even if it’s with another company — than sell you something that is not right for you.

The sea of Mallorca deserves to be enjoyed. Choose how you want to experience it, and do it right.

blog_cuatro.meta_description: A complete guide to choosing between a private or shared boat trip in Mallorca (Alcudia). Real differences, key advantages, when each option is worth it, and local tips to get it right for your boat tour in the Bay of Alcudia.

section1.title: Two ways to experience the sea
section1.body:
Choosing a **boat trip in Mallorca** is often one of the best decisions of the whole holiday—especially if you’re staying in the north of the island. The **Bay of Alcudia** has something addictive about it: calm waters, beautiful light, postcard-worthy coves, and a coastline that becomes even more impressive when you see it from the sea.

But the moment you decide “yes, we’re doing a boat tour,” the big question appears: **private boat tour or shared boat tour?**

And the funny part is: there’s no universal answer. What feels perfect for a couple might be inconvenient for a family with small kids. What’s “the best” for a group of friends might not make sense at all if you’re travelling solo.

In this article, I’ll help you choose with a very realistic approach: not just generic “pros and cons,” but real scenarios, typical decisions, common mistakes, and practical criteria to figure out what suits your travel style.

If you want to browse options while you read, here’s a great starting point with all experiences available: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia). And if you already suspect you’re looking for something exclusive, you can go straight to the most flexible format: [Private boat charter in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-private-boat-charter).

section2.title: Key differences between private and shared tours
section2.body:
Let’s get to the point: **private** and **shared** are not “two versions of the same ride.” They’re two different ways of living the sea.

A **private boat tour** means the boat is only for your group. That usually translates into:

- Freedom to choose the **time slot** (subject to availability).
- The option to adjust the **route and itinerary** to your preferences and sea conditions.
- A flexible pace: spend longer where you want, swim without rushing, take photos at your rhythm.
- A level of intimacy that’s very hard to replicate.

That’s why many travellers choose it for celebrations, romantic escapes, groups that want comfort, or families who want to control timing. If that sounds like you, here’s the direct link to explore it calmly: [Private charter in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-private-boat-charter).

A **shared tour**, on the other hand, is an excursion with seats for different travellers. And here’s the key: when it’s well designed, it’s not just “the cheaper option”—it’s the **social** option.

- You pay per person and it’s usually more accessible.
- The vibe is more dynamic (and sometimes really fun).
- If you travel solo or as a couple, it’s a great way to enjoy a full experience without paying for an entire boat.
- The itinerary is structured so everyone gets a great day.

In practice, lots of travellers who want a smart budget choice—or simply a beautiful experience with zero hassle—go for this option. You can see them all here: [Boat trips from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

And then there are “hybrid” formats in terms of feelings: a morning tour often feels more like “exploration + swimming,” while a sunset tour tends to feel more “romantic + contemplative.” If you want to compare them right now:

- [Morning boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-morning-boat-tour)
- [Sunset boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-sunset-boat-tour)

section3.title: Advantages of each option
section3.body:
To choose well, don’t think only in terms of “price” or “privacy.” Think about what really matters on the day: the pace, the vibe, the level of personalization, whether you’re travelling with kids, whether you feel like meeting people, or whether you want quiet.

Here are the most important advantages of each option—with examples and nuance—because that’s where the real decision happens.

sub1.subtitle: Private boat trip
sub1.body:
A **private boat trip in Mallorca** is usually the best choice when you want the plan to adapt to you—not the other way around.

**Real advantages (the ones you feel onboard):**

- **Total intimacy**: if you’re travelling as a couple, the vibe changes completely. No “social noise,” just sea, coastline, and your own rhythm.
- **Flexibility**: adjusting times is especially useful with small kids (naps), if you want to avoid the strongest sun hours, or if you’re chasing the best light.
- **Celebrations**: birthdays, proposals, anniversaries—or even “just getting everyone together.” Private makes the plan feel like a true event.
- **Pace control**: some groups want lots of swimming; others want more cruising and photos. On a private charter, you decide.

It’s ideal for:

- Families who want safety and full control of timing.
- Groups of friends who value comfort and exclusivity.
- Couples looking for a special experience.

If that fits you, the option is here: [Private boat charter in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-private-boat-charter).

And one important detail: private isn’t “only for the rich.” If you’re a group, the per-person cost often becomes surprisingly reasonable. That’s where it starts to make sense.

sub2.subtitle: Shared boat trip
sub2.body:
A **shared boat trip** works especially well when you want a complete experience without overthinking it—good atmosphere, good value per person, and the easy feeling of just showing up and enjoying.

**Real advantages:**

- **Better price per person**: perfect if you’re travelling solo, as a couple, or in a small group.
- **Social vibe**: some days, meeting other travellers makes the whole trip more fun. You may even walk away with unexpected tips for coves, restaurants, or plans you hadn’t considered.
- **Zero decisions**: you arrive, you board, you enjoy. For many people, that’s exactly what holidays are for.
- **Highly optimized format**: a good shared tour has timings that make the experience feel complete—cruising, stops, swimming, photos.

It’s ideal for:

- Couples who want a romantic plan on a sensible budget.
- Solo travellers who want to experience the sea without paying for a whole boat.
- Families with older kids (when the shared pace isn’t an issue).

If you want to see concrete options, start here: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

And if you know you want a calmer, prettier vibe, sunset is often the favourite: [Sunset boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-sunset-boat-tour).

sub3.subtitle: Still unsure? The question that decides everything
sub3.body:
There’s one question that, if you answer it honestly, usually decides for you:

**Do you want to experience Mallorca as something shared with the world… or as a moment that feels truly yours?**

- If the idea of meeting people, laughing, chatting, and sharing the surprise of the coastline excites you: you’ll probably prefer **shared**.
- If you want silence, uninterrupted photos, your own timings, and a more exclusive feeling: you’ll probably prefer **private**.

And there’s the “trip factor” too: if Mallorca is a special trip (anniversary, proposal, first family holiday, reunion), private tends to leave a deeper mark. If you’re in explore-and-optimize mode, shared is often perfect.

section4.title: Which option fits you best (couple, family, group, or short trip)
section4.body:
This is where we turn everything into real-life scenarios—because that’s what helps most.

**1) Couples**

- If you want something romantic and photogenic: sunset is a safe bet, even as a shared tour. The light is better, the bay looks incredible, and the vibe is usually calmer. See it here: [Sunset boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-sunset-boat-tour).
- If it’s a special occasion (anniversary, proposal) and you want everything to revolve around you: private makes sense. Check this option: [Private charter in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-private-boat-charter).

**2) Families with kids**

- With small children, private gives you full control: schedule, stops, pace, and fewer stimuli. It often feels more enjoyable.
- With kids in “adventure mode” who love fish-spotting and playing in the water, a shared tour can be great fun.

For family-specific ideas (and comfort tips), I recommend this post: [Boat plans for families with kids in Mallorca](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/planes-barco-familias-ninos-mallorca).

**3) Groups of friends**

- For a group, private is often the most complete format: everyone stays together, you can celebrate, set your pace, and make it an event.
- For small groups, shared works brilliantly as an easy “done-for-you” plan—and then you can do dinner or drinks afterwards.

**4) Solo travellers or short getaways**

- If you travel solo, shared is usually the most logical and fun option.
- If you’re only on the island for a few days, a morning tour often feels like you’re “making the most of Mallorca,” while sunset gives you the most emotional, memorable moment.

Practical tip: if it’s your first time or you’re not sure what to bring, this post saves you the classic mistakes: [What to bring on a boat tour in Mallorca](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/que-llevar-a-un-tour-en-barco-mallorca).

And to decide by pure feeling, this is a very useful reference: [Coral Boats Gallery](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/gallery).

section5.title: Our recommendation
section5.body:
If I had to sum it up like a local who’s watched travellers choose (and either love it or regret it) for years, I’d say this:

- **Choose a shared tour** if you want a beautiful, easy plan with a great per-person price and a social touch. It’s perfect for couples, solo travellers, and families who are comfortable with a set pace.
- **Choose a private tour** if you want the experience to adapt to you: timing, pace, intimacy, and a more exclusive feeling. It’s often the best option for celebrations, groups, and families who want full control.

The good news is that in Alcudia you’ve got very clear choices:

- For a complete experience that’s easy to book: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia)
- For more time on the water and a “full-day” feeling: [Morning boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-morning-boat-tour)
- For the most romantic and photogenic moment: [Sunset boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-sunset-boat-tour)
- For the most exclusive, customizable option: [Private boat charter in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-private-boat-charter)

And if you still have specific doubts (pricing for your group, schedules, what fits your kids’ ages, best choice for your dates), the fastest way is to message us here: [Contact Coral Boats](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/contact).

Whichever you choose, one thing never fails: Mallorca feels different when you see it from the sea. And when the bay opens up in front of you, you understand why so many people say this becomes their most remembered moment of the trip.

section1.title: Prepare your maritime adventure in Mallorca
section1.body:
Taking a **boat tour in Mallorca** is one of those experiences every traveler remembers. Turquoise coves, smooth sailing across the Mediterranean, views of the coastline from a different perspective and the feeling of completely disconnecting.

But there is one key detail that makes the difference between a simply good excursion and a truly unforgettable one: **being well prepared**.

At Coral Boats, we have been running boat excursions from Alcudia for years, both shared tours and private experiences. We have seen it all: guests arriving without sunscreen, others forgetting their swimwear, phones damaged by water, or travelers unsure about the right footwear.

That’s why we created this **ultimate guide on what to bring on a boat tour in Mallorca**, designed for:

- Morning boat excursions in the Bay of Alcudia.
- Sunset boat tours.
- Private boat charters.

If you are already thinking about booking your experience, you can see all available options here: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

And if you are still planning your trip, this guide will help you arrive prepared and enjoy every minute at sea.

section2.title: Boat tour essentials
section2.body:
There are several basic items you **should always bring** on any boat excursion in Mallorca, regardless of the tour duration or schedule.

These are the essentials:

- **Sunscreen**: The Mediterranean sun is intense, even on cloudy days. Use high-protection sunscreen, preferably water-resistant. Underestimating the sun at sea is one of the most common mistakes.
- **Towel**: Essential if the tour includes swimming stops or time to relax in coves. Even if you don’t swim, it’s useful for comfort.
- **Swimwear**: Wear it or pack it in your bag. Many travelers regret not bringing it once they see how clear the water is.
- **Water**: Staying hydrated is key, especially in summer. Even if drinks are included, bringing your own bottle is always a good idea.
- **Sunglasses**: Ideally with a strap. Sun glare on the water can be strong and uncomfortable.
- **Camera or phone**: You’ll want to capture the experience. If you’d like inspiration beforehand, you can see real images here: [Coral Boats gallery](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/gallery).

These essentials apply to a **morning tour**, a **sunset excursion**, or a **private charter**. If you haven’t chosen yet, start here: [View boat excursions in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

section3.title: Accessories that will enhance your experience
section3.body:
Beyond the essentials, there are a few accessories that aren’t mandatory but **greatly improve comfort and enjoyment on board**. If your goal is to relax without worrying about anything, these details make a noticeable difference from the very first minute.

And if you’re still deciding which type of excursion suits you best, you can compare options here: [Boat tours in the Bay of Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

sub1.subtitle: Comfortable, non-slip footwear
sub1.body:
Footwear is one of the most common questions. Our recommendation is clear: avoid loose flip-flops and choose **water shoes or non-slip sandals**.

This allows you to move safely around the boat, get on and off comfortably and avoid slipping, especially when the deck is wet.

On excursions such as the **morning boat tour in Alcudia**, where there is more time for swimming and moving around the boat, proper footwear makes a real difference.

You can see full details of this experience here: [Morning boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-morning-boat-tour).

sub2.subtitle: Waterproof bag
sub2.body:
A **waterproof or dry bag** is one of the best allies on any boat tour.

It helps protect:

- Phone
- Documents
- Wallet
- Camera

Even on calm days, splashes are common. Many of the issues we see on board could be avoided simply by using a waterproof bag.

If you want to take photos and videos without worry, combine it with some prior inspiration from our [Boat tour gallery](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/gallery).

sub3.subtitle: Light clothing and a jacket
sub3.body:
During the day, temperatures are usually warm or even hot. But conditions at sea can change quickly.

Especially on:

- **Sunset excursions**
- Breezy days

A **light jacket or sweatshirt** can make the experience far more comfortable.

If you’re considering enjoying a sunset from the sea, we recommend this tour: [Sunset boat tour in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-sunset-boat-tour).

section4.title: Tips to fully enjoy your day at sea
section4.body:
Beyond what to bring, there are a few practical tips that help make the experience truly seamless:

- **Always confirm your booking details** (time, meeting point, duration). If you have any questions, feel free to contact us here: [Contact Coral Boats](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/contact).
- **Arrive early** at the harbor. Starting without rush always improves the experience.
- **If you are prone to seasickness**, take preventive medication before boarding and avoid going on an empty stomach.
- **Listen to the crew**: they know the sea, the wind and the best spots depending on the day.
- **Ask freely**: many experiences can be adapted, especially on a private tour.

If you’re looking for a fully customized experience (schedules, routes, celebrations), check this option: [Private boat charter in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/alcudia-private-boat-charter).

And if you’d like to keep reading and plan more ideas for the area, here’s more content: [Coral Boats blog](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog).

section5.title: Mallorca awaits you for an unforgettable experience
section5.body:
A **boat tour in Mallorca** is not just another travel activity: it’s a way to connect with the island from its most authentic side.

Being well prepared allows you to:

- Relax without worries.
- Enjoy the sea comfortably.
- Make the most of every stop, swim and view.

Whether you choose a shared excursion, a sunset tour or a private boat charter, this checklist will help you experience it the way it truly deserves.

You can explore all our excursions here: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

section1.title: The magic of a sunset in Alcudia
section1.body:
There are places where the sunset is beautiful… and places where it becomes a memory that stays with you for years. Alcudia, on Mallorca’s north coast, belongs to that second group. The combination of the **Bay of Alcudia**, the soft Mediterranean light, and the outline of the **Serra de Tramuntana** creates a show that changes every day: oranges, golds, pinks, and purples blending across the horizon.

The best part is you don’t need to “do anything” to feel it. Just be there at the exact moment. And if you experience it **from the sea**, everything intensifies: the silence, the sun’s reflection on the water, the feeling of open space, and that mental pause that only appears once the coastline falls behind.

If you’re planning your trip, this article will help you understand:

- Why an **Alcudia sunset** is one of the most recommended experiences in Mallorca.
- The difference between watching it from the beach and seeing it **on a sunset boat**.
- What to bring, what to expect, and how to make the most of it.

To get your bearings, here’s a practical guide to the departure point and the vibe of the area: [Port of Alcudia: complete guide](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/guia-puerto-alcudia-mallorca). And if you want to understand the “context” of the bay (why it feels so special), you’ll also enjoy: [The magic of the Bay of Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/magia-bahia-alcudia-tour-barco).

section2.title: Why choose the sea to enjoy the sunset
section2.body:
Watching the sunset from land is stunning, but doing it from the sea completely changes the experience. It’s not just about aesthetics: it’s about perspective, calm, and a sense of travel that begins the moment the boat leaves the port.

From the sea, the perspective changes completely:

- More intense colors reflected on crystal-clear water (the sea acts like a natural mirror).
- A feeling of peace and isolation, away from crowds, noise, and the coastal “rush.”
- Unique panoramic views of the Bay of Alcudia and the Tramuntana Mountains, with a clean, open horizon line.

There’s also a detail many travelers don’t expect: **sunset light from the water is often more photogenic**. On the coast, buildings, beach bars, or trees can interrupt the scene. At sea, everything simplifies: horizon, sky, reflection, and a color palette that feels made for the camera.

If you’re visiting as a couple, it’s one of the most romantic options in the north of the island. If you’re traveling with family, it’s a calm (and different) plan that tends to work for all ages. And if you’re on a short getaway, it’s a “must” that captures Mallorca in just a few hours.

Staying nearby and want to optimize your plans? This article can help: [Things to do in Alcudia: must-do plans](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/que-hacer-en-alcudia-planes-imprescindibles). And if you’re designing a full travel route, here’s a very useful itinerary: [What to see in Mallorca in 3 days](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/que-ver-mallorca-3-dias-itinerario-completo).

section3.title: What the onboard experience is like
section3.body:
A sunset boat trip in Alcudia isn’t “just another activity”: it’s a sensory experience. The air shifts, the noise drops, the pace slows, and the landscape transforms minute by minute. Watching the sunset from the sea includes:

- Departure from the Port of Alcudia and cruising across the bay.
- Time to relax, see the coastline from a new perspective, and let the day fade gently.
- A key moment: when the sun touches the horizon and the water lights up.

If you want to see the available options, here’s the specific trip: [Sunset trip (Sunset Tour)](https://coralboats.com/en/tour-details/sunset-tour). And if you’re comparing different times, you can see all experiences here: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

sub1.subtitle: Calm and relaxing sailing
sub1.body:
Most people describe this part with the same word: **calm**. Sunset cruising in the Bay of Alcudia is usually smooth, with a pleasant breeze and a sea that, on many evenings, feels like glass.

On board, the best approach is to take it slow: choose a good spot, breathe, watch the color of the water, and notice how the coastline gradually turns warm-toned. It’s one of those moments when Mallorca feels “slow” in the best possible way.

Local tip: if you want an even more immersive experience, avoid your phone for the first few minutes and simply watch. It sounds simple, but it’s what turns a ride into a memory.

sub2.subtitle: One-of-a-kind photo moments
sub2.body:
A sea sunset has something that makes it unique: **the reflection**. As the sun drops, the water creates a path of light (golden or orange) that changes every few seconds.

To capture it better:

- Clean your lens before you start (it sounds obvious, but it makes a difference).
- Use portrait mode for people and panoramic mode for the horizon.
- Take one photo at the start, another halfway, and another right at the final moment: they’re three different scenes.

If you also want to add more “dramatic scenery” to your trip, you’ll love exploring the north coast: [Cliffs and secret coves on Mallorca’s north coast](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/costa-norte-mallorca-acantilados-calas-secretas).

sub3.subtitle: A toast at sunset
sub3.body:
A toast isn’t just a drink: it’s the gesture that “closes” the day. That instant when the sun is already low, conversation softens, and everyone understands (without saying it) that they’re living something special.

If you’re traveling as a couple, this is often the most emotional moment. If you’re with friends, it’s when laughter appears and you feel like “this had to happen.” And if you’re traveling with family, it’s a beautiful way to share something different, away from screens and routines.

Tip: if you’re sensitive to motion, have something light to eat before boarding and stay hydrated. The experience is more comfortable—and you’ll enjoy it more.

section4.title: Tips to enjoy the sunset to the fullest
section4.body:
A great sunset trip is even better when you come prepared. These tips are simple, but they make a real difference:

- **Arrive early** at the Port of Alcudia to find the boarding point calmly. This guide helps: [Port of Alcudia: how to get around and where you are](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/guia-puerto-alcudia-mallorca).
- **Bring a light jacket** or sweatshirt: once the sun goes down, the breeze can feel cool, even in summer.
- **Sun protection** if the trip starts with high sun: hat and sunscreen (yes, even in the afternoon).
- **Camera or phone with battery**, and if you have it, a decent night mode for the last minutes.
- **Comfortable footwear**: the port and gangway can be damp.
- **Avoid scheduling something right after** that’s “time-critical.” Sunset needs margin.

If you’re staying in the north, here are ideas to round out the day before or after the sunset cruise: [Things to do in Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/que-hacer-en-alcudia-planes-imprescindibles). And if you’re traveling with kids, this might inspire you: [Boat plans for families with children](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/planes-barco-familias-ninos-mallorca).

section5.title: Experience the sunset from the sea
section5.body:
Watching the sunset in Alcudia from the sea isn’t just “seeing the sun go down.” It’s feeling Mallorca in a different way: more open, quieter, more authentic. It’s that moment when the Mediterranean turns golden and you understand why so many people remember their sunset boat trip as one of the best memories of the whole journey.

If you’d like to experience it with us, you can book directly here:

- [Sunset trip (Sunset Tour)](https://coralboats.com/en/tour-details/sunset-tour)
- [See all boat tours from Alcudia](https://coralboats.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia)

And if you’re building your Mallorca itinerary, complete the experience with an optimized route: [What to see in Mallorca in 3 days](https://coralboats.com/en/blog-details/que-ver-mallorca-3-dias-itinerario-completo).

Mallorca is waiting for you. The sea is too. And when the sky starts to glow, you’ll understand why this plan gets recommended again and again.

section1.title: The Bay of Alcudia: a family paradise
section1.body:
Traveling to **Mallorca with kids** is one of the top choices for many families—and it’s easy to see why. Great weather, fine sandy beaches, shallow waters and a wide range of activities designed for all ages.

Within the island, the **Bay of Alcudia** stands out as an especially family-friendly destination. Areas like **Playa de Alcudia** and **Playa de Muro** offer a safe, spacious and calm environment—perfect for combining relaxation and adventure.

One of the experiences both adults and children enjoy most are **family boat trips**. It’s not just a boat ride: it’s a small sea adventure—sailing, discovering coves, spotting fish, swimming in crystal-clear water and experiencing the Mediterranean from a whole new perspective.

If you’re looking for different things to do with kids during your vacation, a **boat tour from Alcudia** is an option that combines fun, nature and quality family time.

section2.title: Why kids love a boat tour

Here are a few reasons why boat rides are one of the favorite plans for families:

- They feel like little explorers sailing out to sea.

Plus, in areas like Alcudia and Playa de Muro, the sea is often calm, which makes **boat trips with kids** pleasant and safe even for little ones.

sub1.subtitle: Safety on board

This allows parents to relax while kids enjoy the sea with total peace of mind.

sub2.subtitle: Stops in calm coves

These stops often take place near areas like Playa de Alcudia or Playa de Muro, well known for their safety and underwater visibility.

This way, the boat ride turns into a fun and enriching memory for children.

section4.title: Tips for families with kids on a boat tour
section4.body:
To make the experience perfect, here are a few practical tips for families taking **boat trips with kids in Mallorca**:

- Bring **sunscreen**, caps and UV shirts: the sun feels stronger at sea.
- Pack **water and light snacks** to keep kids hydrated and happy.
- Bring **water shoes or non-slip sandals**.

- Tell kids what they’re going to do before boarding to build excitement.

If you have any questions before booking, you can contact us here: [Contact Coral Boats](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/contact).

section5.title: A family experience to remember
section5.body:
Sharing a **family day at sea** is one of those experiences you’ll remember for years. Laughs, discoveries, swims in calm coves and the excitement of sailing together create memories that go far beyond photos.

Whether it’s a morning excursion, a relaxed boat ride or even a **private family tour**, Alcudia offers the perfect setting to enjoy the Mediterranean with kids.

section1.title: The Bay of Alcudia: secrets within reach of only a few
section1.body:
When people think of Alcudia, many imagine long white-sand beaches, calm waters and family holidays. But the **Bay of Alcudia** hides a much wilder, more authentic and lesser-known side.

Along the north coast of Mallorca there are **hidden coves, sea caves and unspoiled spots** that do not appear on traditional tourist maps and that **can only be discovered from the sea**. There are no roads, paths or easy access points. The only way to reach them is by boat.

This is precisely why a **boat tour in Alcudia** becomes much more than a simple ride: it becomes an exploration. A way to access landscapes that remain untouched, far from the crowds and the noise of the most popular beaches.

At Coral Boats, we have been navigating these waters for years, and we know that many travelers are looking for something different: **authentic places**, silence, nature, and that feeling of discovering something truly special.

If you are considering living this experience, you can see all available options here: [Boat tours from Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

section2.title: Five unique places that will surprise you
section2.body:
Below, we show you five secret spots in the Bay of Alcudia that can only be visited by boat. Each one has its own character, but they all share something in common: **natural beauty, tranquility and exclusive access from the sea**.

- **Cala de las Águilas**: a small unspoiled cove surrounded by rocks and Mediterranean vegetation. Its waters are incredibly clear and usually completely calm. Ideal for swimming and disconnecting.

- **The hidden caves of Cap des Pinar**: a set of rocky formations and sea caves that can only be explored by boat. Some allow partial entry by boat, while others are perfect for swimming and snorkeling.

- **S’Illot**: a small island just off the coast, visible from the beach but inaccessible without a boat. Its seabed is perfect for observing fish and enjoying a swim in open water.

- **Es Caló**: a little-known spot with shallow waters and turquoise tones that look straight out of a postcard. An ideal place to relax and enjoy the silence.

- **Coll Baix Beach**: probably one of the most striking landscapes in northern Mallorca. Vertical cliffs, coarse sand and a total sense of isolation. Although there is a walking access, arriving by boat is without a doubt the most comfortable and spectacular way.

You can see real images of these places in our [Boat tour gallery](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/gallery).

section3.title: What makes this experience special?
section3.body: Visiting these secret spots is not just about the scenery, but about **how the experience is lived**. A boat trip along this part of northern Mallorca offers advantages that simply cannot be replicated from land.

sub1.subtitle: A unique perspective
sub1.body:
From the sea, the coastline of Alcudia and Cap des Pinar reveals itself in all its glory. The cliffs, caves and coves are appreciated in a completely different way.

The light, the colors and the contrast between the blue of the Mediterranean and the rock create a feeling that is hard to describe. This is one of the reasons why many travelers consider these **boat routes in Alcudia** to be among the best memories of their trip.

sub2.subtitle: Exclusive access and tranquility
sub2.body:
Many of these spots are **inaccessible by land** or require long hikes. Reaching them by boat allows you to enjoy the place effortlessly and, in many cases, without sharing it with large groups of people.

This translates into calm, privacy and a more authentic connection with the natural surroundings.

sub3.subtitle: Direct contact with nature
sub3.body:
Swimming in crystal-clear waters, snorkeling next to rocky formations, listening only to the sound of the sea and observing marine life in its natural habitat.

These experiences are increasingly valued by travelers seeking **sustainable, mindful tourism away from mass crowds**.

If this type of plan appeals to you, you might also enjoy: [Boat trips for families with children in Mallorca](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/planes-barco-familias-ninos-mallorca).

section4.title: Tips to make the most of your boat tour
section4.body:
To fully enjoy these hidden coves and secret spots, we recommend keeping a few practical tips in mind:

- **Bring snorkeling gear**: many of these areas have spectacular seabeds.
- **Sun protection and a hat**: the sun is more intense at sea.
- **Water shoes**: especially useful in rocky areas or coarse sand beaches like Coll Baix.
- **Waterproof bag** to protect your phone and personal items.
- **Respect the natural environment**: do not leave waste and avoid touching marine wildlife.

If this is your first time in the area, this guide may help you prepare: [What to bring on a boat tour in Mallorca](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/que-llevar-a-un-tour-en-barco-mallorca).

And if you have questions about schedules, sea conditions or the type of excursion, you can write to us here: [Contact Coral Boats](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/contact).

section5.title: Set sail into the unknown
section5.body:
Discovering the secret spots of the Bay of Alcudia is one of those experiences that truly define a trip. It is not just about seeing beautiful places, but about **feeling the island from the sea**, accessing spaces that remain authentic and wild.

A **boat tour in Alcudia** allows you to step away from the usual routes, avoid the crowds and connect with a different Mallorca—more natural, quieter and more genuine.

If you feel like experiencing it firsthand, you can explore all our excursions here:

- [Boat trips in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia)

And if you want to keep discovering the north of the island, we recommend this article: [Things to do in Alcudia: must-see plans](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/que-hacer-en-alcudia-planes-imprescindibles).

The sea holds secrets that only reveal themselves to those who dare to sail. Ready to set off?

section1.title: A maritime paradise in Mallorca
section1.body:
There are places that feel as if they were made to be explored from the sea, and **Alcudia Bay** is one of them. Located in the north of Mallorca, this wide bay combines **calm, crystal-clear waters**, a diverse coastline and a natural setting that invites you to sail at a relaxed pace.

Unlike other more exposed areas of the island, Alcudia Bay offers ideal sailing conditions for most of the year. This makes it one of the best destinations in Mallorca for **boat tours, boat excursions and relaxed boat trips**, both for first-time sailors and for those looking for a more complete experience.

From long sandy beaches such as **Playa de Alcudia** and **Playa de Muro**, to rocky stretches, hidden coves and vibrant seabeds, the bay offers a level of diversity that is hard to match. All of this with the **Serra de Tramuntana** as a dramatic backdrop.

Sailing here is not just about moving from one place to another: it is about observing, feeling and connecting with the Mediterranean. That is why every **boat tour in Alcudia Bay** becomes a unique experience, shaped by the rhythm of the sea and the traveller.

If you would like to experience it yourself, you can explore all available options here: [Boat tours in Alcudia Bay](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/boat-tours-alcudia).

section2.title: Five reasons why Alcudia Bay is unique
section2.body:
Choosing Alcudia Bay for a boat excursion is no coincidence. There are many reasons why it is considered one of the best sailing areas in Mallorca. Here are some of the key ones:

1. **Calm and crystal-clear waters**: The bay is naturally protected from strong winds, resulting in a sea that is usually smooth and easy to navigate. This makes **boat trips in Alcudia** comfortable and safe, even for families with children or first-time sailors.

2. **Hidden coves and sea-access-only spots**: Along the coastline you will find small coves, marine caves and untouched areas that can only be reached by boat. Places where silence and a sense of exclusivity still exist.

3. **Rich marine life and excellent snorkeling**: Sandy and rocky seabeds host fish, seagrass meadows and marine biodiversity that can easily be observed from the surface.

4. **Iconic landscapes of northern Mallorca**: From the sea you enjoy unique views of the coastline, the cliffs of Cap des Pinar and the silhouette of the **Serra de Tramuntana**, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

5. **Historical and cultural landmarks**: Sailing through the bay allows you to see emblematic points such as the **Alcanada Lighthouse**, an iconic image of northern Mallorca combining history, architecture and scenery.

If you enjoy discovering lesser-known places, we recommend this article: [Five secret spots accessible only by boat in Alcudia](https://www.coralboatsmallorca.com/en/blog-details/cinco-rincones-secretos-desde-el-mar-alcudia).

section4.title: Tips for planning your boat tour
section4.body:
To make the most of your experience sailing in Alcudia Bay, keep these practical tips in mind:
